abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: AppKit contains the objects you need to build the user interface for a macOS app. In addition to drawing windows, buttons, panels, and text fields, it handles all the event management and interaction between your app, people, and macOS.

Aside from drawing and managing interactions, AppKit handles printing, animating, as well as creating documents with large amounts of data efficiently. The framework also contains built-in support for localization and accessibility to ensure that your app reaches as many people as possible.

, so you can implement parts of your AppKit app in SwiftUI or mix interface elements between the two frameworks. For example, you can place AppKit views and view controllers inside SwiftUI views, and vice versa.
For information about bringing your iPad app to Mac, see
. To build an iOS app, you can use SwiftUI to create an app that works across all of Apple’s platforms, or use
to create an app for iOS only.

SwiftUI-PageImage-card.png.alt: A black Swift logo on a swirly blue and purple background.

A pattern that indicates the pasteboard detects a string that consists of a numeric value.

A pattern that indicates the pasteboard detects a string that contains a postal address.
A pattern that indicates the pasteboard detects a string suitable for use as a web search term.
A pattern that indicates the pasteboard detects a string that consists of a web URL.

A protocol for suggestion delegates of text fields to conform to in order to provide text suggestions in response to the user typing.
